title: World's most asked questions: how can I get rid of the hiccups?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main topic of discussion in this video?

options.label: A
options.text: How to cure a common cold

options.label: B
options.text: How to get rid of hiccups

multiple-choice.question: What is the diaphragm, and what is its function in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: A sheet of muscle under the lungs that helps with digestion

options.label: B
options.text: A sheet of muscle under the lungs that is essential for breathing

options.label: C
options.text: A sheet of muscle in the throat that helps with swallowing

options.label: D
options.text: A sheet of muscle in the chest that helps with heartbeat regulation

multiple-choice.question: What causes the "hic" sound when a person hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: The sudden contraction of the diaphragm, followed by the vocal folds clamping shut

options.label: B
options.text: The sudden release of air from the lungs, followed by the diaphragm relaxing

options.label: C
options.text: The sudden contraction of the vocal folds, followed by the diaphragm contracting

options.label: D
options.text: The sudden release of air from the throat, followed by the diaphragm relaxing

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to get rid of hiccups by stimulating the vagus nerve?

options.label: C
options.text: Drinking a glass of water quickly

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of carbon dioxide levels in regulating breathing rhythms?

options.label: A
options.text: High CO2 levels signal the diaphragm to contract and cause hiccups

options.label: B
options.text: Low CO2 levels signal the diaphragm to contract and cause hiccups

options.label: C
options.text: High CO2 levels signal the nervous system to regulate breathing rhythms

options.label: D
options.text: Low CO2 levels signal the nervous system to regulate breathing rhythms

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common approach to getting rid of hiccups?

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream

options.label: D
options.text: Drinking a glass of water quickly

title: Learn to use suffixes -le -al -el with the Singing Nun | Educational song

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common usage of the "le" and "el" sounds in words?

options.label: D
options.text: The usage of "el" and "le" depends on the word.

multiple-choice.question: When do you use the "el" sound in words?

options.label: A
options.text: After the letters a, e, i, o, u.

options.label: B
options.text: After the letters m, n, r, v, w.

options.label: C
options.text: After the letters p, q, s, t, x.

options.label: D
options.text: After the letters b, c, d, f, g.

multiple-choice.question: How can you remember when to use the "el" sound after certain letters?

options.label: A
options.text: By thinking of a word that starts with each letter.

options.label: B
options.text: By creating a sentence using the first letter of each word.

options.label: C
options.text: By imagining a camel, tunnel, and travel with a beanie.

options.label: D
options.text: By memorizing a list of words that use the "el" sound.

multiple-choice.question: What are the exceptions to the rule of using "el" after the letters m and n?
Why are the words "signal" and "animal" exceptions to the rule?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they use the "el" sound instead of "le".

options.label: B
options.text: Because they use the "le" sound instead of "el".

options.label: C
options.text: Because they use a different vowel sound.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not English words.

options.label: A
options.text: To explain the usage of the "el" sound.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide an example of a word that uses the "le" sound.

options.label: C
options.text: To help remember the exceptions to the rule.

multiple-choice.question: How can you determine which sound to use, "le" or "el", if you are unsure?

options.label: C
options.text: Look up the word in a dictionary.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To explain the difference between the "le" and "el" sounds.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide examples of words that use the "le" and "el" sounds.

options.label: C
options.text: To discuss the exceptions to the rule of using "el" after certain letters.

options.label: D
options.text: To teach how to remember the usage of the "le" and "el" sounds.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the letters m, n, r, v, w and the "el" sound?

options.label: A
options.text: The "el" sound is used after these letters.

options.label: B
options.text: The "le" sound is used after these letters.

options.label: C
options.text: These letters are exceptions to the rule.

options.label: D
options.text: These letters are not related to the "el" sound.

options.text: Because it starts with the letter "m".

options.label: B
options.text: Because it helps to remember the exceptions to the rule.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a word that uses the "el" sound.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a common word.

title: How do you know if you have a virus? - Cella Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) testing in the context of viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect antibodies in the body

options.label: B
options.text: To diagnose someone who is currently infected with a virus

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the genetic material of a virus

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a treatment for a viral infection

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between PCR testing and immunoassays?

options.label: A
options.text: PCR testing detects antibodies, while immunoassays detect genetic material

options.label: B
options.text: PCR testing detects genetic material, while immunoassays detect antibodies

options.label: C
options.text: PCR testing is used for current infections, while immunoassays are used for past infections

options.label: D
options.text: PCR testing is used for past infections, while immunoassays are used for current infections

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of reverse transcription in PCR testing?

options.label: D
options.text: To identify the genetic material of a virus

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of primers in PCR testing?

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the genetic material of a virus

options.label: D
options.text: To bind to specific regions of the viral genome

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of immunoassays in the context of viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To diagnose someone who is currently infected with a virus

options.label: B
options.text: To detect antibodies in the body

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the genetic material of a virus

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a treatment for a viral infection

multiple-choice.question: What type of antibodies do immunoassays typically detect?
What is the significance of IgM antibodies in immunoassays?

options.label: D
options.text: They indicate immunity to a virus

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of using blood plasma from individuals who have developed immunity to a virus?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be used to diagnose current infections

options.label: B
options.text: It can be used to treat current infections

options.label: C
options.text: It can be used to develop a vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: It can be used to detect antibodies

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of digital PCR over traditional PCR?

options.label: A
options.text: It is faster and more accurate

options.label: B
options.text: It is more sensitive and specific

options.label: C
options.text: It can quantify individual pieces of target DNA

options.label: D
options.text: It is less expensive and more accessible

multiple-choice.question: Why are PCR and immunoassays essential in the context of viral infections?

options.label: C
options.text: They can identify the genetic material of a virus

options.label: D
options.text: They can save millions of lives when deployed early

title: Why do bats carry so many diseases? (like coronavirus)

multiple-choice.question: What is a common factor among the world's scariest viruses such as Nipah, Hendra, Ebola, Marburg, and SARS?

options.label: A
options.text: They are all caused by human error.

options.label: B
options.text: They are all carried by bats.

options.label: C
options.text: They are all spread through contaminated water.

options.label: D
options.text: They are all transmitted through mosquitoes.

multiple-choice.question: What is a likely reason for the recent rise in outbreaks of diseases carried by bats?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats are becoming more aggressive towards humans.

options.label: B
options.text: Humans and their animals are encroaching on bats' territory.

options.label: C
options.text: Climate change is causing bats to migrate to new areas.

options.label: D
options.text: Bats are evolving to become more disease-resistant.

multiple-choice.question: Why do bats appear to carry more human-killing diseases than other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats have a weaker immune system than other animals.

options.label: B
options.text: Bats are more likely to come into contact with humans.

options.label: C
options.text: Bats often roost together in large numbers, allowing viruses to spread easily.

options.label: D
options.text: Bats have a unique genetic makeup that makes them more susceptible to disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is a reason why infected bats often don't die from the diseases they carry?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats have a strong immune system that fights off the disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Bats are able to produce antibodies that neutralize the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: Flight may have helped bats develop resilience to infection.

options.label: D
options.text: Bats are able to transmit the disease to other animals, reducing their own viral load.

multiple-choice.question: How do bats' internal temperatures during flight affect the viruses they carry?

options.label: A
options.text: The high temperatures kill off the viruses.

options.label: B
options.text: The high temperatures have no effect on the viruses.

options.label: C
options.text: The high temperatures allow only certain hardy viruses to survive.

options.label: D
options.text: The high temperatures cause the viruses to mutate into more deadly forms.

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of bats' ability to carry certain viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to transmit the disease to other animals.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps them develop immunity to the disease.

options.label: C
options.text: It enables them to produce antibodies that can be used to treat human diseases.

options.label: D
options.text: It may have helped them gain virtual immunity to viruses and trained viruses to be virtually immune to humans.

multiple-choice.question: Why are bats important to the ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a food source for other animals.

options.label: B
options.text: They provide insect control and pollination services.

options.label: C
options.text: They help to spread seeds and propagate new plant growth.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a source of medicine and other valuable resources.

multiple-choice.question: What can humans learn from bats' immune systems?

options.label: A
options.text: How to produce antibodies that neutralize viruses.

options.label: B
options.text: How to develop resilience to infection through flight.

options.label: C
options.text: How to be really good at not getting cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: How to transmit diseases to other animals.

multiple-choice.question: Who is the biggest carrier of human disease?
What is a suggested solution to reducing the spread of diseases carried by bats?

options.label: A
options.text: Culling bat populations to reduce the number of disease-carrying individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: Leaving bats alone and trying to control the spread of diseases carried by humans.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing vaccines and treatments for bat-borne diseases.

options.label: D
options.text: Educating the public about the risks of bat-borne diseases.

title: Adding '-ed' | Past tense verbs

options.label: A
options.text: Ed is a genius and knows everything about grammar.

options.label: B
options.text: Ed is a time traveler who can travel into the past using verbs.

options.label: C
options.text: Ed is an athlete and excels in every sport.

options.label: D
options.text: Ed is a musician and can play any instrument.

multiple-choice.question: What type of word does Ed need to travel back in time?
What happens to the verb when Ed jumps onto the end of it?

options.label: A
options.text: The verb changes to the present tense.

options.label: B
options.text: The verb changes to the future tense.

options.label: C
options.text: The verb changes to the past tense.

multiple-choice.question: What is the rule to send a verb into the past?

options.label: A
options.text: Add "ing" to the end of the word.

options.label: B
options.text: Add "ed" to the end of the word.

options.label: C
options.text: Add "s" to the end of the word.

options.label: D
options.text: Add "ly" to the end of the word.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a verb that Ed uses to travel back in time?
What is the past tense of the verb "look"?
What is the past tense of the verb "play"?
What is the past tense of the verb "want"?
What is the past tense of the verb "work"?
Why does Ed add "ed" to the end of a verb?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To change the verb to the future tense.

options.label: C
options.text: To change the verb to the past tense.

title: What is a coronavirus? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: What was the source of the deadly new virus that caused an epidemic of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats in the mountains of China

options.label: B
options.text: Bats in the caves of Africa

options.label: C
options.text: Mosquitoes in the forests of Asia

options.label: D
options.text: Rodents in the deserts of North America

multiple-choice.question: What is the characteristic feature of coronaviruses that gives them their name?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to cause severe respiratory illness

options.label: B
options.text: Their protein spikes that resemble a crown

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to infect a wide range of hosts

multiple-choice.question: How many human coronaviruses are known to cause disease, and what are some examples of the diseases they cause?
How do coronaviruses transmit from person to person?

options.label: A
options.text: Through direct contact with an infected person

options.label: B
options.text: Through droplets containing the virus that are sprayed out when an infected person coughs

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between RNA viruses and DNA viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: RNA viruses are larger and more complex than DNA viruses

options.label: B
options.text: RNA viruses have a proofreading mechanism, while DNA viruses do not

options.label: C
options.text: RNA viruses tend to be smaller and have fewer genes than DNA viruses

options.label: D
options.text: RNA viruses are more stable and have a slower mutation rate than DNA viruses

multiple-choice.question: Why do RNA viruses tend to have a higher mutation rate than DNA viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a proofreading mechanism that introduces errors

options.label: B
options.text: Because they lack a proofreading mechanism, which allows errors to accumulate

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a larger genome that is more prone to errors

options.label: D
options.text: Because they replicate more quickly and produce more offspring

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about coronaviruses compared to other RNA viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: They are smaller and have fewer genes

options.label: B
options.text: They have a proofreading mechanism that corrects errors

options.label: C
options.text: They are more stable and have a slower mutation rate

options.label: D
options.text: They are more contagious and cause more severe illness

multiple-choice.question: Why is the slow mutation rate of coronaviruses a promising sign for disarming them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it makes it harder for the virus to adapt to new hosts

options.label: B
options.text: Because it makes it easier for the virus to evade the immune system

options.label: C
options.text: Because it allows the immune system to recognize the virus for longer

options.label: D
options.text: Because it makes it harder to develop effective treatments and vaccines

multiple-choice.question: Why do we need a new flu vaccine every year?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the influenza virus mutates quickly and new strains emerge

options.label: B
options.text: Because the influenza virus is highly contagious and causes severe illness

options.label: C
options.text: Because the influenza virus is resistant to antiviral drugs

options.label: D
options.text: Because the influenza virus is a coronavirus

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern about the potential for a new coronavirus to jump from animals to humans?

options.label: A
options.text: That it will cause a mild and self-limiting illness

options.label: B
options.text: That it will be easily contained and eradicated

options.label: C
options.text: That it will cause a severe and devastating pandemic

options.label: D
options.text: That it will be impossible to develop effective treatments and vaccines

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of eating healthy food

title: Native Americans for kids: Cherokee, Apache, Navajo, Iroquois and Sioux

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean to be a Native American?

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Fabulous food chains

multiple-choice.question: What is the main source of energy for all living things in a food chain?
What is a food chain?

options.label: A
options.text: A model that shows how energy flows between living things

multiple-choice.question: What do plants use to capture energy from the Sun?
What happens to the energy from a plant when an animal eats it?

options.label: B
options.text: The energy is transferred to the animal's body

options.label: C
options.text: The energy is stored in the soil

options.label: D
options.text: The energy is released into the air

multiple-choice.question: What is an ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: A self-contained collection of different things that all work together as a whole

multiple-choice.question: What do food chains show us about an ecosystem?

options.label: D
options.text: What type of habitat it is

multiple-choice.question: Why are most living things in more than one food chain?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they eat the same thing every day

options.label: B
options.text: Because they eat different things at different times

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are at the top of the food chain

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are at the bottom of the food chain

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the energy from an animal when another animal eats it?

options.label: B
options.text: The energy is transferred to the other animal's body

options.label: C
options.text: The energy is stored in the soil

options.label: D
options.text: The energy is released into the air

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of plants in a food chain?

options.label: A
options.text: To capture energy from the Sun and change it into chemical energy

options.label: B
options.text: To eat animals and transfer energy

options.label: C
options.text: To release energy into the air

options.label: D
options.text: To store energy in the soil

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because it provides energy for animals to eat

options.label: C
options.text: Because it provides energy for the ecosystem to function

title: Why don't haircuts hurt?

multiple-choice.question: Why doesn't it hurt when you get a haircut?

options.label: A
options.text: Because haircuts are done by professionals.

options.label: B
options.text: Because hair doesn't have nerves inside it.

options.label: C
options.text: Because haircuts are done with special scissors.

options.label: D
options.text: Because hair is not a part of the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main job of nerves in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To carry messages between different places in the body.

options.label: C
options.text: To digest food in the stomach.

options.label: D
options.text: To breathe air in and out of the lungs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the sense that nerves help us with, which allows us to feel things?
What happens when something touches our skin?
Where do the messages from our nerves travel to?
What is the brain's role in our sense of touch?

options.label: A
options.text: To send messages to our nerves.

options.label: B
options.text: To decode the messages from our nerves.

options.label: D
options.text: To breathe air in and out of the lungs.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't our hair feel our fingers when we touch it?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our hair is too thin.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our hair doesn't have nerves inside it.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our fingers are too rough.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our hair is too long.

multiple-choice.question: What is another part of our body that doesn't have nerves inside it, like our hair?
Why doesn't it hurt when we cut our fingernails or toenails?

options.label: B
options.text: Because our fingernails and toenails don't have nerves inside them.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not a part of the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why we don't feel pain when we get a haircut?

options.label: A
options.text: Because haircuts are done by professionals.

options.label: B
options.text: Because hair doesn't have nerves inside it.

options.label: C
options.text: Because haircuts are done with special scissors.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our brain doesn't send pain signals.

title: Why is my leg asleep?

multiple-choice.question: What is the tingling, prickly feeling in your arm or leg called when it has been numb and then starts to get feeling back?
Why do people say that an arm or leg "fell asleep" when it becomes numb?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is actually sleeping like the rest of the body at night.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is numb and can't feel much, like it is sleeping.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a medical term for numbness.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a type of injury.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the blood vessels when you sit in one position or lean on your arm or leg for a while?

options.label: A
options.text: They get bigger and more blood flows through.

options.label: B
options.text: They stay the same size and the same amount of blood flows through.

options.label: C
options.text: They get smaller and less blood flows through.

options.label: D
options.text: They disappear and no blood flows through.

multiple-choice.question: Why do nerves need blood to work properly?

options.label: A
options.text: So they can move around the body.

options.label: B
options.text: So they can send signals to the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: So they can feel sensations like touch and temperature.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the nerves when they don't get enough blood?

options.label: C
options.text: They stop working and the area becomes numb.

multiple-choice.question: Why do nerves get confused when they start getting blood again after being numb?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they need time to adjust to the new blood flow.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are sending wrong signals to the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What can you do to help get rid of the pins and needles feeling?

options.label: A
options.text: Shake the affected arm or leg.

options.label: B
options.text: Rub the affected arm or leg.

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for a minute or two.

multiple-choice.question: How can you prevent getting pins and needles?

options.label: A
options.text: By sitting in one position for a long time.

options.label: B
options.text: By leaning on your arm or leg for a long time.

options.label: C
options.text: By moving around regularly and not sitting or leaning in one position for too long.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of nerves in the body?

options.label: B
options.text: To send signals to the brain about sensations like touch and temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: To pump blood throughout the body.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important for blood to flow through all parts of the body?

options.label: A
options.text: So the body can move around.

options.label: B
options.text: So the body can feel sensations like touch and temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: So the body can get energy and work properly.

title: Plurals -s -es | Learn to Spell

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the machine that makes more than one of something?
What is the special tail that indicates a plural called?

When should you use "es" instead of "s" to form a plural?
What are some examples of words that use "es" to form a plural?
What is the purpose of the pluralator machine?

options.label: C

title: Closed and open syllables | Learn to read

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the vowel sound in an open syllable?

options.label: D
options.text: It changes to a different vowel sound.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an open syllable?
What happens to the vowel sound in a closed syllable?

options.label: D
options.text: It changes to a different vowel sound.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words is an example of a closed syllable?
What is the rule for vowel sounds in open and closed syllables?

options.label: A
options.text: Open syllables make a short sound, and closed syllables say the letter name.

options.label: B
options.text: Open syllables say the letter name, and closed syllables make a short sound.

options.label: C
options.text: Open syllables become silent, and closed syllables make a short sound.

options.label: D
options.text: Open syllables make a short sound, and closed syllables become silent.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words are open syllables?
What is the difference between an open and a closed syllable?

options.label: A
options.text: An open syllable has one vowel, and a closed syllable has two vowels.

options.label: B
options.text: An open syllable says the letter name, and a closed syllable makes a short sound.

options.label: C
options.text: An open syllable makes a short sound, and a closed syllable says the letter name.

options.label: D
options.text: An open syllable has a consonant at the end, and a closed syllable does not.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a closed syllable?

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel says its letter name.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel makes a short sound.

options.label: D
options.text: The syllable has a consonant at the beginning.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a word that is a closed syllable?
What is the main idea of the rule for open and closed syllables?

options.label: A
options.text: Vowels always make a short sound.

options.label: B
options.text: Vowels always say their letter name.

options.label: C
options.text: The position of the vowel determines its sound.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of vowels determines the sound.

title: The L-iminator! | The double L spelling rule

multiple-choice.question: What is a compound word?

options.label: A
options.text: A word that is broken down into two separate words.

options.label: B
options.text: A new word formed by joining two words together.

options.label: C
options.text: A word that is used to describe a verb.

options.label: D
options.text: A word that is used to describe a noun.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the double "L" when two words join together to form a compound word?

options.label: A
options.text: The double "L" is retained in the compound word.

options.label: C
options.text: The double "L" is replaced with a single "M".

options.label: D
options.text: The double "L" is replaced with a double "T".

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of eliminating one of the "L"s in a compound word?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the word more complex.

options.label: B
options.text: To make the word easier to pronounce.

options.label: C
options.text: To make room for another letter.

options.label: D
options.text: To follow the rule that there is only room for one "L" in a compound word.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of a compound word?
What is the meaning of the word "eliminate" in the context of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove or get rid of something.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the word "elves" in the context of the transcript?
What is the tone of the speaker in the transcript?
What is the main topic of the transcript?
What is the speaker trying to convey to the listener?

options.label: A
options.text: The complexity of the English language.

options.label: C
options.text: The rules of forming compound words.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final message of the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To always follow the rules of grammar.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the rules of compound words.

title: Human, capital & natural resources for kids | Types of resources

multiple-choice.question: What is a resource?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Something that people use to meet their needs.

options.label: C
options.text: Something that people find in nature.

options.label: D
options.text: Something that people use to travel.

options.label: B
options.text: Human resources, capital resources, and natural resources.

options.label: C
options.text: Human resources, financial resources, and natural resources.

options.label: D
options.text: Capital resources, financial resources, and natural resources.

options.label: C
options.text: Things that are found on earth and can be used by people.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a human resource?

multiple-choice.question: What are capital resources?

options.label: A
options.text: Goods that are made and used to provide a service.

options.label: C
options.text: Things that are found on earth and can be used by people.

options.label: D
options.text: Tools and equipment needed to make goods.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a capital resource?

options.label: A
options.text: Goods that are made and used to provide a service.

options.label: C
options.text: Things that are found on earth and can be used by people.

options.label: D
options.text: Tools and equipment needed to make goods.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a natural resource?

options.label: B
options.text: A doctor who helps people feel better.

multiple-choice.question: What is a service?

options.label: A
options.text: Something that someone makes for you.

options.label: B
options.text: Something that someone does for you.

options.label: C
options.text: Something that you use to meet your needs.

options.label: D
options.text: Something that you find in nature.

multiple-choice.question: What are goods?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Things that someone does for you.

options.label: C
options.text: Things that you use, eat, or drink.

options.label: D
options.text: Things that you find in nature.
